fields.name: RiTa.VERSION
fields.description: the current RiTa version

fields.name: RiTa.isAbbreviation
fields.description: Returns true if 'input' is an abbreviation

returns.desc: true if 'input' is an abbreviation

fields.name: RiTa.isQuestion
fields.description: Returns true if sentence starts with a question word

returns.desc: true if 'sentence' starts with a question word

fields.name: RiTa.env
fields.description: Returns one of the following constants, depending on the runtime environment (RiTa.JAVA, RiTa.JS, RiTa.ANDROID, RiTa.NODE)

returns.desc: Returns RiTa.JAVA, RiTa.JS, RiTa.ANDROID or RiTa.NODE, depending on the runtime environment

fields.name: RiTa.isSentenceEnd
fields.example:
text = "The dog ate the small baby. Then it threw up.";
words = text.split(" ");
RiTa.isSentenceEnd(words[5], words[6]); // returns true
RiTa.isSentenceEnd(words[3], words[4]); // returns false
fields.description: Takes two consecutive words and returns true if 'currentWord' is the final word of a sentence (if true, 'nextWord' is generally the first word of the next sentence)

returns.desc: true if 'currentWord' is the final word of a sentence

fields.name: RiTa.isW_Question
fields.description: Returns true if sentence starts with a w-question word, eg (who,what,why,where,when,etc.)

returns.desc: true if sentence starts with a w-question word, eg (who,what,why,where,when,etc.)

fields.name: RiTa.randomItem
fields.description: Returns a random item from an array (or Collection)

returns.desc: the item

fields.name: RiTa.randomOrdering
fields.description:
Returns a randomly ordered array of unique integers from 0 to numElements.
The size of the array will be numElements.

returns.desc: unique integers from 0 to numElements-1

fields.name: RiTa.splitSentences
fields.example: RiTa.splitSentences(""The boy went fishing.", he said. Then he went away.");
fields.description: Splits 'text' into sentences (according to PENN Treebank conventions)

parameters.desc: text the text to be split
regex (optional) the pattern to be used for word tokenization

returns.desc: array of sentences

fields.name: RiTa.stripPunctuation
fields.description: Strips all punctuation from the input string

returns.desc: result

fields.name: RiTa.trimPunctuation
fields.description: Trims punctuation from both ends the input string (does not trim whitespace or internal punctuation)

returns.desc: result

fields.name: RiTa.isPunctuation
fields.description: Returns true if every character of 'text' is a punctuation character

fields.name: RiTa.tokenize
fields.description:
Tokenizes a string (into words) according to Penn Treebank conventions
See: ftp://ftp.cis.upenn.edu/pub/treebank/public_html/tokenization.html

parameters.desc: regex (optional) the pattern to be used for tokenization

returns.desc: in which each element is a single token (or word)

fields.name: RiTa.untokenize
fields.description:
Joins an array (of words and punctuation) into a String, according to Penn Treebank conventions
See: ftp://ftp.cis.upenn.edu/pub/treebank/public_html/tokenization.html

returns.desc: in which the elements have been joined into a single string

fields.name: RiTa.minEditDistance
fields.description: Takes a pair of strings or string-arrays and returns the minimum edit distance between them (the number of additions, subtractions, or modifications it takes to go from one to the other)

parameters.desc: normalize (optional) if true, normalizes the distance based on the length of the strings

returns.desc: the minimum-edit distance

fields.name: RiTa.distance
fields.description: Convenience method to get the distance between 2 points

returns.desc: the distance

fields.name: RiTa.getPhonemes
fields.example:
RiTa.getPhonemes("apple"); // returns -> ae-p-ah-l

RiTa.getPhonemes("two apples"); // returns -> t-uw ae-p-ah-l-z
fields.description: Returns a string containing all phonemes for the input text

returns.desc:
e.g., 'ae-n eh-l-ax-f-ax-n-t ih-z ey m-ae-m-ax-l'
(for 'An elephant is a mammal')

fields.name: RiTa.getPosTags
fields.description: Uses the default PosTagger to tag the input with tags from the PENN tag set or the simplified WordNet tag set [a, r, v, n]

parameters.desc: if true, use WordNet syle tags (optional, default=false)

fields.name: RiTa.getPosTagsInline
fields.description:
Takes an string returns a combined string of the form:

'The/dt doctor/nn treated/vbd dogs/nns'
, using lowercased tags from the PENN tag set

returns.desc: a combined string of words and pos tags

fields.name: RiTa.getStresses
fields.description: Analyzes the input and returns a new string containing the stresses for each syllable of the input text

returns.desc: e.g., '01-0-1', with 1's meaning 'stressed', and 0's meaning 'unstressed',

fields.name: RiTa.getSyllables
fields.description: Analyzes the input and returns a String containing the phonemes for each syllable of each word of the input text,  delimited by dashes (phonemes) and spaces (words)

returns.desc: e.g., 'dh-ax d-ao-g r-ae-n f-ae-s-t' for the 4 syllables of the phrase 'The dog ran fast'

fields.name: RiTa.getWordCount
fields.description: Returns the # of words in the String according to the default tokenizer

returns.desc: the # of words

fields.name: RiTa.concordance
fields.example:
// Java

Map args = new HashMap();
args.put("ignoreCase", false);
args.put("ignoreStopWords", true);

String c = RiTa.concordance(text, args);


// Javascript

var args = {
ignoreCase: false,
ignoreStopWords: true
};

var c = RiTa.concordance(text, args);
fields.description: Creates a concordance, a list of words with their frequency of occurence, from the given text and (optional) options

parameters.desc:
options (optional) the relevant options for the KWIK model:

{int} options.wordCount:
# of words of context on either side of input word

{boolean} options.ignoreCase:
Ignore upper/lower case in the model

{boolean} options.ignoreStopWords:
Ignore words like 'the', 'and', 'a', 'of', etc, as specified in RiTa.STOP_WORDS

{boolean} options.ignorePunctuation:
Ignore punctuation tokens in the model

{String[]} options.wordsToIgnore:
A set of words (alternative stop-words, for example) to ignore.

returns.desc: the concordance

fields.name: RiTa.kwic
fields.example:
// Java

Map args = new HashMap();
args.put("ignoreCase", false);
args.put("ignoreStopWords", true);

String[] lines = RiTa.kwic(text, args);


// Javascript

var args = {
ignoreCase: false,
ignoreStopWords: true
};

var lines = RiTa.kwic(text, args);
fields.description: Creates a Key-Word-In-Context (KWIC) model from a given text, a word to lookup, a wordCount and (optional) options

parameters.desc:
options (optional) the relevant options for the KWIC model:

{int} options.wordCount:
# of words/punctuation of context on either side of input word

{boolean} options.ignoreCase:
Ignore upper/lower case in the model

{boolean} options.ignoreStopWords:
Ignore words like 'the', 'and', 'a', 'of', etc, as specified in RiTa.STOP_WORDS

{boolean} options.ignorePunctuation:
Ignore punctuation tokens in the model

{String[]} options.wordsToIgnore:
A set of words (alternative stop-words, for example) to ignore.

returns.desc: all the occurrences of the keyword in the model, each with 'wordCount' words of context on either side

fields.name: RiTa.conjugate
fields.example:
// Java

Map args = new HashMap();
args.put("tense", RiTa.PAST_TENSE);
args.put("number", RiTa.SINGULAR);
args.put("person", RiTa.FIRST_PERSON);

String c = RiTa.conjugate("swim", args);


// Javascript

var args = {
tense: RiTa.PRESENT_TENSE,
number: RiTa.SINGULAR,
person: RiTa.THIRD_PERSON
};

var c = RiTa.conjugate('swim', args);
fields.description: Conjugates the 'verb' according to the specified options

parameters.desc: args containing the relevant options for the conjugator

returns.desc: the conjugated verb

fields.name: RiTa.getPastParticiple
fields.description: Returns the past participle form of the stemmed or non-stemmed 'verb'

returns.desc: the past participle form of the verb

fields.name: RiTa.getPresentParticiple
fields.description: Returns the present participle form of the stemmed or non-stemmed 'verb'

returns.desc: the present participle form of the verb

fields.name: RiTa.stem
fields.description:
Extracts base roots from a word according to the specified stemming algorithm
 
Note: see http://text-processing.com/demo/stem/ for comparison of Lancaster and Porter algorithms or http://mpii.de/yago-naga/javatools for info on PlingStemmer

parameters.desc: Choose RiTa.PORTER (the default), RiTa.LANCASTER, or RiTa.PLING, to specify the stemming algorithm to use

returns.desc: the stemmed form of 'word'

fields.name: RiTa.pluralize
fields.description: Pluralizes a noun according to pluralization rules

returns.desc: the regular or irregular plural form of the noun

fields.name: RiTa.singularize
fields.description: Singularize a word according to singularization rules

returns.desc: the singular form of the noun

fields.name: RiTa.timer
fields.description: Starts a timer that calls 'onRiTaEvent()', or the specified callback (in JS), every 'period' seconds

parameters.desc: the parent object in which to find (optional in JS)

callback function to be called every 'period' seconds
the function name String (in Java) or the function itself (in JS)

returns.desc: the unique id for the timer

fields.note: The 'parent' object is optional in JS, and the optional callback is a function, rather than a String name

fields.name: RiTa.stopTimer
fields.description: Stops a timer according to its unique id

parameters.desc: the unique id for the timer

fields.name: RiTa.pauseTimer
fields.description: Pauses a timer according to its unique id (and assigns a new unique id)

parameters.desc: the unique id for the timer

returns.desc: the new unique id for the timer

fields.name: RiTa.random
fields.example:
RiTa.random(0,1.0)// to get a float between 0, 1

RiTa.random(10) // to get an int between 0,10
fields.description: Returns a random number between >= min (default=0) and < max (default=1)

returns.desc: the random number (its type depends on input parameters)

fields.note: if only one parameter is supplied, it is read as the max-value (with min=0)

fields.name: RiTa.loadString
fields.example:
txt = RiTa.loadString("kafka.txt");
txt = RiTa.loadString('kafka.txt', callbackFun); // JS
txt = RiTa.loadString("kafka.txt", this, " ");   // Java
fields.description: Loads the contents of a file or URL and then calls back to the supplied 'callback' function with the loaded string as an argument.
fields.syntax:
RiTa.loadString(url);

RiTa.loadString(url, callback);
RiTa.loadString(url, pApplet);

RiTa.loadString(url, callback, str);
RiTa.loadString(url, pApplet, str);

parameters.desc: the filename from which to load the file

A callback (in JS) or a PApplet (in Java)
If a callback function, it will be called after the file is loaded, with the loaded string as its argument
with which to join the lines of the string (default = '\\n') -- in some cases, a space character may be more useful

fields.note: In Node, uses the node 'filesystem' or 'request' modules; in JavaScript, uses an XMLHttpRequest; in Java, if a Processing PApplet is passed as a 2nd argument, it will be used to locate and check the 'data' folder of the sketch for the specified file

fields.name: RiTa.addWord
fields.description: Adds a word to the current lexicon. Note: will replace the word if it already exists

fields.name: RiTa.clear
fields.description: Clears the lexicon

fields.name: RiTa.containsWord
fields.description: Returns true if the word exists in the lexicon (case-insensitive)

fields.name: RiTa.alliterations
fields.description: Finds alliterations by comparing the phonemes of the input string to those of each word in the lexicon

parameters.desc: minimum length of word to return (optional, default=4)

returns.desc: array of alliterations

fields.name: RiTa.lexicalData
fields.description:
Allows one to set/get the raw dictionary data used to create the default lexicon.

See RiTa.addWord() for data format

parameters.desc: Optional: a map (HashMap in Java, Object in JavaScript) that maps words to their pronunciation and part-of-speech data

returns.desc: lexical data map (for gets)

fields.name: RiTa.randomWord
fields.description: Returns a random word from the lexicon. When arguments are supplied part-of-speech and/or syllable-count will be matched as well

returns.desc: random word

fields.name: RiTa.rhymes
fields.description: Two words rhyme are considered as rhyming if their final stressed vowel and all following phonemes are identical

returns.desc: rhymes for word, or an empty array if none are found

fields.name: RiTa.words
fields.description:
Returns the array of all words in the lexicon or those matching a specific regex.
If specified, the order of the result array is randomized before return.

returns.desc: all (or the matching) words in the lexicon

fields.name: RiTa.isAdverb
fields.description: Returns true if the word has an adverb form. That is, if any of its possible parts of speech are any variant of an adverb in the PENN part-of-speech tag set (e.g. rb, rbr, rbs)

returns.desc: true if the word can be used as an adverb

fields.name: RiTa.isNoun
fields.description: Returns true if the word has a noun form. That is, if any of its possible parts of speech are any variant of a noun in the PENN part-of-speech tag set(e.g. nn, nns, nnp, nnps)

returns.desc: true if the word can be used as a noun

fields.name: RiTa.isVerb
fields.description: Returns true for if word has a verb form. That is, if any of its possible parts of speech are any variant of a verb in the PENN part-of-speech tag set (e.g. vb, vbg, vbd, vbp, vbz)

returns.desc: true if the word can be used as a verb

fields.name: RiTa.isAdjective
fields.description: Returns true if word has an adjective form. That is, if any of its possible parts of speech are any variant of an adjective in the PENN part-of-speech tag set (e.g. jj, jjr, jjs)

returns.desc: true if the word can be used as an adjective

fields.name: RiTa.isAlliteration
fields.description: Returns true if the two words are alliterations (iff the first stressed consonant of the two match). Note: returns true if wordA.equals(wordB) and false if either (or both) are null.

returns.desc: true if the first stressed consonant of the two words match

fields.name: RiTa.isRhyme
fields.description:
Returns true if the two words rhyme, that is, if their final stressed vowel phoneme and all following phonemes are identical, else false.

Note: returns false if word1.equals(word2) or if either (or both) are null;

parameters.desc: use letter-to-sound rules if not found in lexicon (optional, default=true)

returns.desc: true if the two words rhyme, else false.

fields.name: RiTa.reload
fields.description: Clears then reloads the default lexicon

fields.name: RiTa.similarByLetter
fields.description: Compares the characters of the input string  (using a version of the min-edit distance algorithm) to each word in the lexicon, returning the set of closest matches.

parameters.desc: minimum edit distance for matches (optional, default=1)
whether to return only words that match the length of the input word (optional, default=false)

returns.desc: the matching words

fields.name: RiTa.similarBySound
fields.description: Compares the phonemes of the input word (using a version of the min-edit distance algorithm) to each word in the lexicon, returning the set of closest matches.

parameters.desc: minimum edit distance for matches (optional, default=1)

returns.desc: the matching words

fields.name: RiTa.similarBySoundAndLetter
fields.description:
First calls similarBySound(), then filters the result set by the algorithm used in similarByLetter();

(useful when similarBySound() returns too large a result set)

returns.desc: the matching words

fields.name: RiTa.size
fields.description: Returns the number of words currently in the lexicon

returns.desc: the # of words

fields.name: RiTa.substrings
fields.description: Returns all valid substrings of the input word in the lexicon

parameters.desc: minimum length of return word (optional, default=4)

returns.desc: the matching words

fields.name: RiTa.superstrings
fields.description: Returns all valid superstrings of the input word in the lexicon

returns.desc: the matching words
